pr_title: fix: encode attribute value during transfer from embedded web app

timeline.message: fix: encode attribute value during transfer from embedded web app
fix: encode only path and query separately

timeline.bodyText: Hm. URLEncoder.encode is for encoding parameters for using in application/x-www-form-urlencoded data, it changes forward slash (perfectly valid in path part of URL) to %2f.
timeline.author: fluorumlabs

replies.bodyText:
The forward slash is not a problem : encoded slash is recognized correctly in the URI.
Encoded ? is an issue.
But if not URLEncoder.encode  then which way do you suggest to escape/encode here ?
replies.author: denis-anisimov

replies.bodyText: One particular problem is whitespace character: in path it should be encoded as %20 whereas URLEncoder.encode encodes it as +. The real solution is to either escape single quote to avoid injection, or, possibly, use double quotes in JS (double quote is not allowed in URL AFAIR)
replies.author: fluorumlabs

replies.bodyText:
Why it is a problem ?
Single quote is not always a single quote.
The problem is : you have to detect whether the symbol ' is a single quote or not.
E.g. \' is not a single quote.
And %27 is also a single quote.
Please provide a code which escapes single quote.

or, possibly, use double quotes in JS (double quote is not allowed in URL

double quote is not allowed. But I don't understand the sentence.
replies.author: denis-anisimov

replies.bodyText:
or, possibly, use double quotes in JS (double quote is not allowed in URL

It's really hard to decrypt what you mean sometimes.
Do you suggest to use double quotes in the code which creates JS content inside transferAttribute?

timeline.bodyText: Since this method doesn't returns argument as is, it should probably return boolean instead and called isUrlUnsafe to align with com.vaadin.flow.server.HandlerHelper#isPathUnsafe. The IllegalArgumentException should be thrown in modifyPath then.

replies.bodyText:
This is an internal private method and it's name and how it's called is a  matter of taste .
The method returns the provided argument as is without any change and it throws the exception if something wrong with the argument.
It works quite similar to the Objects::requireNonNull.
